880e606a-bb23-4f1b-94c4-105024443ec4.summary: Can reasons be causes when actions seem spontaneous?
880e606a-bb23-4f1b-94c4-105024443ec4.content: {There is a plausible principle that actions caused by reasons are not spontaneous.}, {Spontaneous actions appear to occur without a preceding discernible cause.}, {If reasons are causes of actions, then actions should not appear spontaneous.}

32999f5c-f3f4-4803-a4a9-d27766338a44.summary: Does mental causation solve the exclusion problem?
32999f5c-f3f4-4803-a4a9-d27766338a44.content: {There is a plausible principle that if a mental state causes an action, it must not be excluded by a physical cause.}, {Every physical event has a sufficient physical cause.}, {If a reason is a mental state causing an action, this might be excluded by its sufficient physical cause.}

5473c178-a8b1-42ee-a82d-0c510d73d463.summary: Can reasons be simultaneous with their effects?
5473c178-a8b1-42ee-a82d-0c510d73d463.content: {There is a plausible principle that a cause must precede its effect.}, {If a reason is a mental state that coincides temporally with an action, it is simultaneous with its effect.}, {If reasons are causes, they should not be simultaneous with their effects.}

0eb71d88-93a0-43a8-96e4-93d8190f2ee7.summary: Can the same reason be a cause of different actions?
0eb71d88-93a0-43a8-96e4-93d8190f2ee7.content: {There is a plausible principle that a single cause cannot produce different effects independently.}, {A person could have the same reason yet perform different actions in different contexts.}, {If reasons are causes of actions, the same reason should not logically lead to different actions.}

780699bd-24fb-4fa8-a33f-0cd2fa3019d4.summary: Are unconscious reasons causes of actions?
780699bd-24fb-4fa8-a33f-0cd2fa3019d4.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {Unconscious mental states are those that an agent is not aware of.}, {If a reason is a cause, it implies the need for awareness of that mental state.}

f43f0021-37cc-4a16-83e3-aff51a3fd9e4.content: {Habitual actions are often automatic and do not involve conscious deliberation.}, {A reason is a mental state.}, {As causes of actions, reasons should involve conscious mental states.}

4a8ec144-4c8a-4b26-be93-a0329c966e21.summary: Does the variability of reasons challenge their causal role?
4a8ec144-4c8a-4b26-be93-a0329c966e21.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {Different reasons might cause the same action in different circumstances.}, {Causes should produce consistent effects to be causally efficacious.}

592933e6-e46f-44f1-b53b-f85d0c483a52.summary: Can reasons explain actions that are contrary to an agent’s reasons?
592933e6-e46f-44f1-b53b-f85d0c483a52.content: {There is a plausible principle that a cause should explain its effect accurately.}, {People sometimes act against their own better reasons knowingly.}, {Such actions challenge the causal explanatory role of reasons.}

bd5221e9-920d-450e-b91d-d83b0a7487dd.summary: Are reasons irreducible to physical causes?
bd5221e9-920d-450e-b91d-d83b0a7487dd.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {Mental states are often considered as irreducible to physical states.}, {Causes must be identifiable in concrete terms to be effectively explanatory.}

c97471a5-f5eb-4174-b64a-557432bf8bc7.summary: Can all reasons for actions be rooted in desires?
c97471a5-f5eb-4174-b64a-557432bf8bc7.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {Desire-based reasoning cannot explain actions motivated by duty or obligation.}, {If reasons are causes, they should extend beyond mere desires to encompass duties.}

f258a909-d23e-47f1-85ab-b0e6f3686f47.summary: How do reasons as causes account for moral responsibility?
f258a909-d23e-47f1-85ab-b0e6f3686f47.content: {A reason is a cause of an action.}, {Moral responsibility often requires freedom from causal determination.}, {If reasons are causes, the agent’s freedom and moral accountability might be undermined.}

48328fdd-e467-45ae-878e-99dd645a991c.summary: Do rational beliefs qualify as causes in the same way as desires?
48328fdd-e467-45ae-878e-99dd645a991c.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {Beliefs and desires differ in their roles in action initiation.}, {If reasons are causes, both beliefs and desires should fit uniformly into causal explanations.}

c2e965bc-2a67-4bca-b146-54ac3c4403fd.summary: Can reasons still be causes if they are reasons for not acting?
c2e965bc-2a67-4bca-b146-54ac3c4403fd.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {There are mental states that justify inaction or restraint.}, {If reasons are causes of actions, they should not lead to non-occurrence of actions.}

746bd4c5-c14c-4f25-a7ca-d3aa04615be8.summary: Is it possible for the same mental state to be both a reason and a cause?
746bd4c5-c14c-4f25-a7ca-d3aa04615be8.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {A reason provides a causal explanation of the action.}, {It is questionable whether a mental state can both justify and cause an action.}

6c9b7dd4-dccc-4f68-a840-6af85f1f478b.summary: How do cases of weakness of will fit the model of reasons as causes?
6c9b7dd4-dccc-4f68-a840-6af85f1f478b.content: {A reason is a cause of an action.}, {In weakness of will, agents act against their best reasons.}, {If reasons are causes, it is unclear how agents act against them.}

c6a04358-18f1-47c0-bbcd-b945a132d225.summary: Do reasons presuppose awareness that undermines causal efficacy?
c6a04358-18f1-47c0-bbcd-b945a132d225.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {Causes do not require conscious awareness by the agent.}, {The causal role of reasons might be compromised if awareness is requisite.}

d740d183-ba9e-42c8-a418-147d3632276e.summary: Can reasons as causes assure consistent predictability of actions?
d740d183-ba9e-42c8-a418-147d3632276e.content: {Predictability requires a consistent cause-effect relationship.}, {A reason is a mental state.}, {Reasons often lead to unpredictable actions in varying contexts.}

16ad6577-4e24-4be1-8aad-4c0c35413004.summary: Are reasons causally efficient if they compete with environmental factors?
16ad6577-4e24-4be1-8aad-4c0c35413004.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {Environmental factors can deterministically influence actions.}, {For reasons to be effective causes, they should not be subverted by environmental determinants.}

b3c5cec7-6b2e-451a-8b73-866cd45c9daa.summary: Can reasons be legitimate causes in light of free will?
b3c5cec7-6b2e-451a-8b73-866cd45c9daa.content: {A reason is a cause of an action.}, {Free will implies actions are not entirely caused by preceding conditions.}, {The idea of free will raises questions about reasons as deterministic causes.}

2cf84096-64e1-4aee-a2ad-087f54402ef4.summary: Does the multiplicity of potential reasons undermine their causal role?
2cf84096-64e1-4aee-a2ad-087f54402ef4.content: {A reason is a mental state.}, {Individuals can have multiple, even conflicting, reasons resulting in a single action.}, {This multiplicity raises concerns about clarifying which reason causally explains the action.}

30fc64fd-a9f5-4138-9d75-8d0ce78f1391.summary: Can a reason provide justification without leading to rational action?
30fc64fd-a9f5-4138-9d75-8d0ce78f1391.content: {Consider a scenario where someone has a reason to take an umbrella because it might rain yet they forget to take it. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that having the reason did not make their action of leaving the umbrella rational.}, {There is a plausible principle that if reasons make an action rational, then the action should at least conform to that reason or the agent should follow the consideration. This principle together with the scenario where the person forgets the umbrella entails that the reason did not make their action rational.}

6ea3ab43-a0c1-4cf2-8cf9-d9a3dc19eeb2.summary: Does a morally wrong action have a justification if done for a reason?
6ea3ab43-a0c1-4cf2-8cf9-d9a3dc19eeb2.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person steals money to feed their hungry family. Intuitively, we either have to say that the action is justified because it is done for a good reason, or that the action is not justified because stealing is morally wrong. If we say the action is justified, then this contradicts the idea that morally wrong actions cannot be justified. If we say the action is not justified, then it seems to contradict the reason being a justification.}

400e7f60-825d-467f-9722-5506156bb232.summary: Can a bad reason still count in favor of an action?
400e7f60-825d-467f-9722-5506156bb232.content: {Consider a scenario where someone lies to avoid a minor inconvenience. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the reason to lie counts against moral principles.}, {There is a plausible principle that a consideration cannot count in favor of an action if it inherently conflicts with significant moral principles. This principle together with the scenario of lying for minor convenience suggests that bad reasons do not genuinely count in favor of an action.}

cd52d2e6-b5ed-4b54-891d-b3ec16a0c176.summary: Do reasons always align with rationality when emotions are involved?
cd52d2e6-b5ed-4b54-891d-b3ec16a0c176.content: {Consider a scenario where an emotional reaction leads someone to act impulsively, such as yelling during a heated argument. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the emotional reason drives action but does not necessarily make it rational.}, {It is implausible that emotions always align with rational decision-making, as emotional impulses can lead to irrational actions, even when they provide a reason.}

588fe451-3c6a-4cb4-a8c7-cc49d88a1568.summary: Is it possible for a reason to count in favor of an action without justifying it?
588fe451-3c6a-4cb4-a8c7-cc49d88a1568.content: {There is a plausible principle that a reason providing justification implies a certain moral or rational endorsement of the action. This principle suggests that mere considerations that suggest an action without endorsing it may not truly justify.}, {Suppose we have a case in which someone considers yelling at a subordinate to assert authority. Intuitively, we either have to say that such a reason counts in favor or not. If it counts in favor but lacks moral endorsement, it indicates a gap between counting in favor and justifying.}

0815d894-88b4-41d4-9e07-ba67ef090591.summary: Can reasons exist independently of motivations?
0815d894-88b4-41d4-9e07-ba67ef090591.content: {There is a plausible principle that an action can be performed without a conscious motivation.}, {An individual might perform an action based on a principle or duty rather than a motivation.}, {This suggests that reasons for action do not always align with motivations or desires.}

c2549947-d0e9-48e8-9643-2d51d543de43.summary: Are all reasons tied to subjective desires and beliefs?
c2549947-d0e9-48e8-9643-2d51d543de43.content: {Consider a scenario where an agent desires to harm others and believes it is right.}, {A reason for an action should not always reflect harmful desires.}, {The existence of moral reasons that contradict harmful beliefs challenges the idea that reasons are merely reflections of desires and beliefs.}

e5d6fb27-00fb-41fc-8bc4-7fd9a9b69347.summary: Are ethical reasons always motivationally effective?
e5d6fb27-00fb-41fc-8bc4-7fd9a9b69347.content: {Ethical reasons often exist even when individuals lack motivation to follow them.}, {There are cases where people acknowledge ethical requirements but lack the motivation to act on them.}, {This challenges the claim that reasons always provide motivational force for actions.}

02fc4653-5b4b-47a7-91eb-7fb83964d5d8.summary: Can reasons have an objective status?
02fc4653-5b4b-47a7-91eb-7fb83964d5d8.content: {A plausible principle is that some reasons are objective and not dependent on personal motivations.}, {For example, reasons based on universal moral truths or facts do not rely on individual desires or beliefs.}, {This suggests that reasons can exist independently of personal motivations.}

e2b21416-ff38-45f0-9f37-afae9fb42651.summary: Do reasons perform a guiding function beyond motivation?
e2b21416-ff38-45f0-9f37-afae9fb42651.content: {Reasons can guide actions by offering rational justification independent of motivations.}, {A person might have reasons to act based on logical consistency, even if not motivated.}, {This indicates that reasons have a guiding role beyond merely being motivations.}

ffc44c7d-2742-4bb2-a7f2-5e21f26f8e5c.summary: Is every motivation grounded in a reason?
ffc44c7d-2742-4bb2-a7f2-5e21f26f8e5c.content: {Suppose someone acts purely on impulse without reflection or desire.}, {Such cases show actions without clear reasons, challenging the view that reasons always provide motivation.}, {It is not evident that every motivation is backed by a reflective or articulate reason.}

e4d90dc0-829c-4584-8917-a58b912806a7.summary: Can reasons be overridden by stronger motivations?
e4d90dc0-829c-4584-8917-a58b912806a7.content: {Intuitively, stronger motivations might lead individuals to act contrary to reasons.}, {Consider a person motivated by fear to act unreasonably, despite knowing better reasons.}, {This raises doubt about whether reasons always provide the motivational force for actions.}

0fa5a044-aba1-486f-ae10-08752f646ba2.summary: Do akrasia cases undermine reason-motivation link?
0fa5a044-aba1-486f-ae10-08752f646ba2.content: {Akrasia occurs when a person acts against their better judgment or reason.}, {There are situations where someone knows the best reason for an action but lacks the motivation to follow it.}, {This suggests that reasons do not always equate to motivational force.}

6779baf4-d867-47c6-8d29-3442c66eec5b.summary: Are altruistic actions explained by self-interest reasons?
6779baf4-d867-47c6-8d29-3442c66eec5b.content: {Altruistic actions often occur without direct personal benefit or self-interest motivation.}, {Individuals might perform altruistic acts based on ethical reasons rather than self-motivations.}, {This questions the assumption that reasons must always align with self-interested motivations.}

89e505f5-3202-48fb-8815-0803fed3dba5.summary: Can reasons exist beyond individual belief systems?
89e505f5-3202-48fb-8815-0803fed3dba5.content: {There are reasons that transcend individual belief systems, like universal ethical tenets.}, {These reasons are not contingent on any single agent's desires or beliefs.}, {This challenges the notion that reasons must reflect an agent's personal beliefs.}

42e35293-9253-4ac6-90af-27e398d32df6.summary: Can reasons as normative standards include subjective elements?
42e35293-9253-4ac6-90af-27e398d32df6.content: {There is a plausible principle that reasons should take into account an individual's subjective perspective.}, {An objective standard of correctness might overlook relevant subjective details in guiding actions.}, {A reason that fails to incorporate subjective elements may not adequately determine what an agent ought to do.}

1b2b2f0b-c376-4c68-9a27-b2328863c264.summary: Do reasons always determine the same action for every agent?
1b2b2f0b-c376-4c68-9a27-b2328863c264.content: {A concrete scenario where two agents have the same objective reasons can lead to different actions being appropriate for each.}, {In such a scenario, intuitively, a reason must accommodate differing personal circumstances or values.}, {It is implausible that a single reason applies uniformly without variation in every context.}

bf1e7725-ac1e-4eae-8c78-cb466156ab07.summary: Do reasons as objective standards ignore motivational aspects?
bf1e7725-ac1e-4eae-8c78-cb466156ab07.content: {There is a motivational aspect to reasons that may not be captured by purely objective standards.}, {A concrete case where a reason aligns with objective reality but fails to motivate the agent suggests missing subjective interplay.}, {It is plausible that reasons should motivate as well as guide actions.}

5d6e4e3f-5d77-41fe-9110-6442a51b927f.summary: Can objective reasons conflict with moral intuitions?
5d6e4e3f-5d77-41fe-9110-6442a51b927f.content: {A moral intuition may sometimes conflict with an objective standard of correctness.}, {In a situation where an action is prescribed by objective reasons but feels morally wrong, intuitive judgment may oppose the action.}, {It is implausible that normative standards should completely override moral intuitions without consideration.}

66e5f03c-59d2-44c9-b77f-90665f5bd1e2.summary: Do reasons accommodate personal goals and projects?
66e5f03c-59d2-44c9-b77f-90665f5bd1e2.content: {A reason should consider an individual's personal goals and projects to guide actions effectively.}, {A purely objective standard may fail to align with personal aspirations and long-term objectives.}, {It is plausible that a reason ought to integrate both objective standards and personal commitments.}

f566ad91-36a7-4d10-ac94-adb0fca765d7.content: {There is a plausible principle that reasons incorporate emotional and psychological factors beyond rationality.}, {A case where an agent follows a reason based upon rationality alone may lead to an outcome lacking emotional engagement.}, {It is implausible that reasons are effective guides if they ignore emotional and psychological states.}

78f762a7-fc5e-43bd-827c-f54313e73ec2.summary: Can objective standards be too rigid?
78f762a7-fc5e-43bd-827c-f54313e73ec2.content: {Objective standards of correctness may introduce an undesirable rigidity in decision-making processes.}, {A scenario where an agent faces a unique situation that does not fit the prescribed normative standard challenges the flexibility of reasons.}, {It is plausible that reasons should offer some degree of flexibility to adapt to complex real-world situations.}

81a93645-1210-42a4-a5a2-60c220afe4c6.content: {A reason that fails to consider cultural differences may not be universally applicable.}, {In a multicultural context, an objective standard might conflict with varying cultural norms and values.}, {It is plausible and intuitive that reasons should adapt to cultural contexts to remain relevant.}

aa852966-cc46-4816-8e34-8f277681d903.summary: Are reasons universally applicable to all agents?
aa852966-cc46-4816-8e34-8f277681d903.content: {A universally applicable reason might not be feasible given the diversity of human experiences and perspectives.}, {A scenario where two agents with differing backgrounds and knowledge have conflicting appropriate actions suggests limits to universal applicability.}, {It is implausible that a single correct action exists for every agent under the same reason.}

c0c6d41b-d93c-43ca-9ab3-dd87cf0eac3c.summary: Do reasons give enough weight to past actions and experiences?
c0c6d41b-d93c-43ca-9ab3-dd87cf0eac3c.content: {A reason should take into account an agent's past actions and experiences when guiding future actions.}, {A purely objective approach might overlook significant past events that shape an agent’s decision-making and judgment.}, {It is plausible that a comprehensive reason includes past contextual factors as part of its standard.}

7deca888-a4ac-4bb9-afe0-28bc46595485.summary: Can reasons exist without serving as evidence for a belief?
7deca888-a4ac-4bb9-afe0-28bc46595485.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person P has a reason to act out of moral obligation, yet this reason is not evidence for any specific belief related to a factual proposition. Intuitively, we recognize that reasons can exist independently of evidential support for beliefs.}, {There is a plausible principle that reasons can exist for actions or attitudes other than beliefs. This principle suggests that not all reasons are tied to evidential support for belief formation.}

10fc57d6-9bee-446d-8736-2eb0dded934d.summary: Are all reasons linked explicitly with truth-support?
10fc57d6-9bee-446d-8736-2eb0dded934d.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person P believes a comforting lie that has no evidence supporting its truth, but the belief serves a psychological need. Intuitively, we might say that the psychological benefit is a reason for maintaining the belief, even if it does not support the truth.}, {A person mourning a loss may hold onto beliefs that provide comfort though they lack truth support, suggesting the presence of non-truth-supportive reasons.}

05442c68-af44-4061-9c14-8b7ff8bacfcb.summary: Are reasons always related to an agent's knowledge or understanding?
05442c68-af44-4061-9c14-8b7ff8bacfcb.content: {Consider a child who acts on a reason given by a parent without fully understanding it—an appeal to blind trust rather than comprehension. Intuitively, we judge this can still be a valid reason for action.}, {It is implausible that all reasons must be connected to the agent’s understanding, as individuals often act on reasons without full comprehension or knowledge.}

a0d3c0e4-2944-4ef6-bc3f-436182c1c753.summary: Can a reason fail to support any proposition's truth?
a0d3c0e4-2944-4ef6-bc3f-436182c1c753.content: {There is a plausible principle that reasons for certain emotions, like fear, can be disconnected from factual accuracy or truth-support. This principle can lead to situations where someone has a reason to feel afraid without the correlated belief being true.}, {Suppose someone fears flying due to a traumatic experience, even when there is no evidence that flying is unsafe. Intuitively, we recognize the fear as reasonable, though it does not derive from truth-supporting evidence.}

492a406f-f7eb-4087-9996-3ba727fbbef6.summary: Is evidence always necessary for a reason to be valid?
492a406f-f7eb-4087-9996-3ba727fbbef6.content: {Consider a scenario in which an artist has a non-evidential reason to pursue a creative endeavor, driven by inspiration rather than evidence. Intuitively, inspiration can serve as a valid reason without evidential basis.}, {Not all reasons require evidential support, as evident in domains like art or personal projects where motivation rather than evidence drives action.}

67b5e5d7-f8ee-4f08-b64c-c1df19058627.summary: Can reasons serve purposes beyond supporting belief truth?
67b5e5d7-f8ee-4f08-b64c-c1df19058627.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person P is motivated by ethical reasons to volunteer, independent from supporting any truth about the state of the world.}, {Ethical reasons can drive actions without being tied to the support of propositional truth, illustrating a broader aspect of what a reason might entail.}

e73cc5b5-ac6e-4438-9d6d-450dc1f232eb.summary: Are pieces of evidence the sole constituents of reasons?
e73cc5b5-ac6e-4438-9d6d-450dc1f232eb.content: {A person might follow a tradition out of respect for cultural norms, where the reasons are constituted by social practices rather than evidence. Intuitively, this constitutes a kind of rationale detached from factual evidence regarding propositions.}, {It is implausible to constrain all reasons to be evidence-based, given that cultural and traditional contexts often provide reasons that lack strict evidential grounding.}

b01e81ae-6bab-497a-b6b5-af5b910aebbb.summary: Can reasons exist independently of supporting propositions?
b01e81ae-6bab-497a-b6b5-af5b910aebbb.content: {There is a plausible principle that motivational reasons, such as emotions or desires, don't necessarily support propositions but still serve as reasons for actions.}, {Consider when someone feels moved to help others out of compassion. This compassion acts as a reason, yet it does not align directly with any propositional truth in itself.}

7e0106c7-ef25-4cc5-b984-45607e809cf0.summary: Is it necessary for a reason to be linked with an agent’s understanding?
7e0106c7-ef25-4cc5-b984-45607e809cf0.content: {It is implausible that all reasons are connected to an agent’s understanding, as individuals can follow authority or expertise without grasping underlying concepts.}, {An example is a medical patient following a doctor's advice without understanding the medical rationale, based on trust rather than understanding.}

0208fec5-a842-43a8-857c-5db45a960a71.summary: Do reasons necessarily entail supporting evidence for truth?
0208fec5-a842-43a8-857c-5db45a960a71.content: {In cases where individuals act on hope, hope might sustain beliefs or actions without corresponding to any direct evidence for truth.}, {A terminally ill patient continuing treatment might find hope a sustaining reason even without evidence of success, suggesting a reason beyond evidence for truth.}

92cd4a6b-f46f-4e7b-8e39-405efb4d45c5.summary: Can reasons for actions ever be reasons for beliefs?
92cd4a6b-f46f-4e7b-8e39-405efb4d45c5.content: {Some reasons are applicable to forming beliefs in addition to guiding actions.}, {A reason can be based on evidence and pertain to the truth of a belief rather than just the consequences of an action.}, {Consider a scenario where a medical diagnosis is based on symptoms; the reason for the diagnosis pertains to accuracy of the belief rather than its consequences.}

c8c23dc5-c1a7-4782-82f3-bf6f631cc896.content: {Not all reasons are related to the outcomes or consequences of actions.}, {Some reasons are based on moral duties or obligations regardless of outcomes.}, {Consider that telling the truth is often seen as a duty unrelated to the consequences it might bring.}

035fec49-77f8-4ff2-bf39-f1c397f7668f.summary: Do reasons guide decisions only in practical and not theoretical contexts?
035fec49-77f8-4ff2-bf39-f1c397f7668f.content: {Theoretical reasoning can guide practical decision-making through the formation of true beliefs.}, {Consider that sound theories in physics guide not just understanding but practical applications, showing reasons to apply both in theory and practice.}, {Decisions often require both practical reasoning about outcomes and theoretical reasoning about facts.}

1cb12054-05fe-4f5d-8aea-ae36075b6cbb.summary: How do reasons relate to intentions behind actions?
1cb12054-05fe-4f5d-8aea-ae36075b6cbb.content: {The justification of an action can be tied to the intentions behind it rather than just the consequences.}, {Consider an act of charity done with good intentions can be praiseworthy even if the outcome is not beneficial.}, {Reasons must account for these intentions as part of the practical reasoning process.}

3971feff-b63c-4e9d-9aa0-9c28df6114c7.content: {Not all practical reasoning is exclusively oriented towards achieving goals or outcomes.}, {Consider an artist creating art as an end in itself, without concern for any other outcome.}, {Practical decisions can stem from values or intrinsic motivations not reducible to goals.}

a7479ea6-486a-4e3f-9163-f50dba668fef.summary: Are there cases where practical reasons conflict with consequence-based reasoning?
a7479ea6-486a-4e3f-9163-f50dba668fef.content: {Practical reasons can conflict with reasoning based solely on consequences.}, {Consider a situation where one must keep a promise despite knowing the consequence is harmful; the reason to keep the promise is not based on its outcome.}, {This conflict indicates reasons are not strictly aligned with outcome-based considerations.}

78274074-9626-4d5f-9654-ff0ec2aa0008.summary: Can practical contexts be divorced from logical reasoning?
78274074-9626-4d5f-9654-ff0ec2aa0008.content: {Practical contexts often depend on logical reasoning and not purely on outcomes.}, {An engineer designing a bridge must use logical and theoretical principles rather than simply focusing on practical outcomes.}, {Decision-making in practical contexts often requires a basis in logical coherence and sound reasoning.}

443a1483-4b8e-4fc9-b6a9-665830a8d1b2.summary: Are immediate outcomes the sole concern of practical reasons?
443a1483-4b8e-4fc9-b6a9-665830a8d1b2.content: {Practical reasons need not focus solely on immediate outcomes.}, {Consider a person saving money for retirement; the reason pertains to long-term consequences rather than immediate outcomes.}, {Some decisions are guided by reasons considering long-term benefits.}

b059406d-b026-4ddc-93f0-df005339bc9a.summary: Can reasons guide without leading to a decision?
b059406d-b026-4ddc-93f0-df005339bc9a.content: {Reasons can exist without necessarily leading to a practical decision.}, {A philosophical analysis might produce reasons for various interpretations without resulting in a conclusive decision.}, {The role of some reasons is to inform or guide rather than directly decide.}

c45083b7-2151-4242-8442-b12a2dd48aac.summary: Is action always the primary focus of reasons?
c45083b7-2151-4242-8442-b12a2dd48aac.content: {The primary focus of some reasons may be understanding or interpreting rather than driving action.}, {Scholarly investigation can be driven by reasons aimed at expanding knowledge, with no direct link to action.}, {Reasons may apply to theoretical pursuits as much as to practical endeavors.}

ce8f110b-fd3d-4a8e-bb56-6adf46cf16ee.summary: Can reasons exist independently of an agent's desires?
ce8f110b-fd3d-4a8e-bb56-6adf46cf16ee.content: {It is implausible that all reasons are derived solely from an agent's existing desires and motivations.}, {Consider a scenario in which an individual has no desire to prevent harm to others. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the individual still has a reason to prevent harm, counter to their desires.}

9c8e82c1-8941-425a-bb5a-00c655c694ed.summary: Is full awareness necessary for a reason to motivate?
9c8e82c1-8941-425a-bb5a-00c655c694ed.content: {Suppose we have a case in which an agent is unaware of a critical piece of information that would alter their desire. Intuitively, we either have to say that they have a reason even without awareness or that they don't. If we say they don't, it seems counterintuitive because the information is relevant regardless of their awareness.}, {There is a plausible principle that reasons should motivate relevant actions even when an agent lacks full awareness. This principle suggests that awareness isn't a necessary condition for a reason to exist.}

d8622117-d4e6-4dfd-9a7c-db987b3b9c71.summary: Are subjective perspectives sufficient for determining reasons?
d8622117-d4e6-4dfd-9a7c-db987b3b9c71.content: {It is implausible that reasons are fully accessible within an agent's subjective perspective alone.}, {Consider a scenario where an agent is deeply prejudiced, skewing their perspective. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the agent's perspective fails to access the full set of reasons relevant to their actions.}

bf22d0ff-93be-4177-a94e-ce882b061d3d.summary: Do reasons depend solely on existing desires?
bf22d0ff-93be-4177-a94e-ce882b061d3d.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person desires only self-destructive outcomes. Intuitively, we would judge that they have reasons to act contrary to these desires, indicating that reasons do not solely depend on existing desires.}, {It is implausible that morally significant reasons could be dependent solely on contingent desires.}

3c8d0971-c10c-4f98-acb7-6fd85a21d78e.summary: Can reasons conflict with an agent's motivations?
3c8d0971-c10c-4f98-acb7-6fd85a21d78e.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person is motivated by spite. Intuitively, we either have to say that reasons support acting on this spite or that they oppose it. If reasons support it, it allows for morally questionable behavior without critique.}, {There is a plausible principle that reasons should guide away from acting on malicious motivations, suggesting an independence from some motivations.}

02844f1a-e992-4a13-aaa5-8f0c31a7cb3d.summary: Can we have reasons we are unaware of?
02844f1a-e992-4a13-aaa5-8f0c31a7cb3d.content: {Consider a scenario where an external observer identifies a reason for an agent's action that the agent is unaware of. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that this reason is valid despite the agent's lack of awareness.}, {There is a plausible principle that reasons can exist independently of an agent's awareness, inferred from observational angles.}

f6b09351-ffae-4971-8ae1-50540bbe7eac.summary: Is the subjective perspective always reliable for discovering reasons?
f6b09351-ffae-4971-8ae1-50540bbe7eac.content: {It is implausible that an agent's subjective perspective is always reliable in distinguishing their true reasons.}, {A case in which a person is under severe cognitive bias highlights that their subjective perspective may not accurately reflect the reasons they should consider. Intuitively, this case shows subjective perspectives can be unreliable.}

b8d8419f-a038-4d9d-a37a-73748320530d.summary: Can an agent lack the motivation that reasons imply they should have?
b8d8419f-a038-4d9d-a37a-73748320530d.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person does not feel motivated to save someone in peril. Intuitively, we either have to say that they lack a reason or that they have a reason despite lacking motivation. If we say they lack a reason, it seems counterintuitive because the moral importance of saving remains.}

4e065649-c82d-43b0-8870-09c0dd25b232.summary: Can reasons derive from external objective factors rather than internal desires?
4e065649-c82d-43b0-8870-09c0dd25b232.content: {There is a plausible principle that reasons can originate from objective considerations about the world independent of any individual's desires.}, {Consider a scenario in which a law mandates evacuation due to natural disaster. Intuitively we would judge that everyone has a reason to comply because of the objective risk, irrespective of personal desires.}

b1086ee3-4a79-4b5b-b429-91f4c4c3040e.summary: Can external evaluations highlight significant reasons missed by the agent?
b1086ee3-4a79-4b5b-b429-91f4c4c3040e.content: {A scenario wherein third parties identify rational reasons for an agent's action that the agent does not acknowledge highlights that significant reasons might be missed due to an agent's subjective perspective.}, {It is plausible that third-party evaluations can uncover reasons not apparent to one's internal deliberation, signaling a limitation in subjective access to reasons.}

756df34e-3db5-409a-914a-00f717a826a8.summary: Can reasons exist without reference to one's desires?
756df34e-3db5-409a-914a-00f717a826a8.content: {A case in which an individual has no desire or motivation to prevent harm to another person is not a case in which the individual is seen to have a reason to act to prevent harm.}, {In a situation where no motivation exists for a person to act, it is implausible that there is a reason compelling them to act.}, {It is implausible that reasons exist in the absence of any motivational force within an agent.}

7e214cf8-fbe1-4957-b010-118f995451db.summary: Do reasons remain compelling if they are divorced from personal subjective perspectives?
7e214cf8-fbe1-4957-b010-118f995451db.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person is unaware of any potential negative consequences of not acting, intuitively we would judge that they are not compelled by any reason to act.}, {Suppose an agent lacks any information about a situation's moral or practical implications, it is implausible that such an agent has a reason to act.}, {A plausible principle suggests that awareness or personal perspective is necessary for reasons to be compelling in guiding behavior.}

295f0055-4e90-42ec-b0b7-d16f3929a5ae.content: {A reason that is purported to exist independently of subjective perspectives cannot be experienced or identified in a concrete manner.}, {It is implausible that reasons are objective entities as they require an interpreter to assess their validity or applicability.}, {Consider a principle where objective entities are independently verifiable, intuitively reasons seem to require context or interpretation by an agent to be meaningful.}

72e0e1a5-acd0-4e63-b34d-e4248f88bd57.summary: Can practical actions be justified without subjective input?
72e0e1a5-acd0-4e63-b34d-e4248f88bd57.content: {Consider a situation where an action leads to personal harm, with no personal motivations or desires to avoid harm, it is not intuitive that a reason exists to avoid the action.}, {A practical reason that prescribes action despite potential personal detriment without consideration of subjective input appears unjustified.}, {The absence of subjective justification in determining an action's value questions the existence of independent reasons.}

0e2c590b-dcc2-4039-9c49-807c0085a59d.summary: Is a reason applicable to someone who lacks any awareness of it?
0e2c590b-dcc2-4039-9c49-807c0085a59d.content: {Suppose a person exists without any awareness of a particular reason, it is implausible that the reason affects their decision-making process.}, {If a reason exists without the agent's awareness or understanding, it fails to influence practical reasoning in any meaningful way.}, {Consider an agent oblivious to a reason, intuitively, a reason unknown and irrelevant to an agent's context lacks applicability.}

6ee8298f-9479-4d68-b1b5-84d1764aa463.summary: Can reasons enforce actions uniformly across differing subjective situations?
6ee8298f-9479-4d68-b1b5-84d1764aa463.content: {A situation in which two agents face the same factual scenario but have differing desires and motivations is not one in which the same reason compels both.}, {A plausible principle is that compelling reasons require some resonance with an agent's specific desires or circumstances.}, {It is implausible that a reason applies uniformly without considering subjective and contextual differences.}

9c616e42-9f60-4104-a7e9-69848e8a0b01.summary: Does the existence of external reasons undermine autonomy?
9c616e42-9f60-4104-a7e9-69848e8a0b01.content: {If reasons exist independently of an agent's motivations, autonomy over decision-making could be compromised.}, {A plausible principle holds that autonomy requires control over one's reasons and motivations, not dictated by independent external factors.}, {The concept of external reasons implies an imposition on personal choice, suggesting that autonomy is undermined.}

469a137b-39fe-4491-889a-9459e6ee4ffd.summary: Are external reasons compatible with varied cultural norms?
469a137b-39fe-4491-889a-9459e6ee4ffd.content: {Suppose cultural norms influence what is seen as reasonable, then a reason that is objective might conflict with these norms.}, {Different cultures prioritize actions and reasons diversely, making uniform external reasons challenging to apply universally.}, {It is implausible that objective, independent reasons align with the diverse value systems of different cultures.}

834b5b95-6387-4dd3-9a38-2367afb06897.summary: Can an action be justified purely by objective reasoning?
834b5b95-6387-4dd3-9a38-2367afb06897.content: {Consider a scenario where an action chosen purely for its objective reason leads to negative consequences in a personal context, this suggests the reasoning is insufficient.}, {An action justified without personal input lacks sensitivity to the specific needs and circumstances of the actor's situation.}, {Objective reasoning that disregards personal or contextual variables often fails to account for holistic ethical and practical evaluations.}

78979f45-247a-4ba5-bcab-f42eb3e4df3b.summary: Is there coherence between the objectivity of reasons and evolving moral standards?
78979f45-247a-4ba5-bcab-f42eb3e4df3b.content: {If moral standards evolve with societal change, static external reasons may not adapt appropriately to new ethical paradigms.}, {Objective reasons struggle to align with the dynamic nature of societal and moral shifts.}, {It is implausible that reasons independent of subjective influence remain valid amidst changing moral landscapes.}

cc74dc18-c6c7-48d3-9c5f-99c0c406a676.summary: Can reasons always be explanations given differing levels of understanding?
cc74dc18-c6c7-48d3-9c5f-99c0c406a676.content: {Consider a scenario in which an agent performs an action without fully understanding the reason behind it. Intuitively, we would judge that a reason cannot serve as an explanation for the action if the agent lacks understanding.}, {It is implausible that a reason which the agent does not comprehend could clarify the rationale behind a choice.}, {Suppose we have an instance where someone acts out of habit rather than rational deliberation. Intuitively, these habitual actions do not have reasons linked to understanding the causal history of actions.}

e50f5106-6b51-450e-85c6-b56600daba2c.summary: Is every reason necessarily causal in nature?
e50f5106-6b51-450e-85c6-b56600daba2c.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person claims, "I am helping because it is kind." Intuitively, "kindness" serves as a motivational reason but not a direct causal explanation for any specific action.}, {It is implausible that abstract ethical reasons, like believing something is "good," can be deeply tied to specific causal histories of actions.}

142032ad-6f65-454d-a11b-2f32be9bbabd.summary: Can irrational actions still have valid reasons?
142032ad-6f65-454d-a11b-2f32be9bbabd.content: {Consider a case in which a person acts against their better judgment, such as eating unhealthy food when trying to be healthy. Intuitively, such actions can be explained by a weakness of will, not a clarifying rationale.}, {Suppose there is a case where someone lies out of fear rather than reasoned decision-making. Intuitively, the causal history involving fear does not equate to a reason that clarifies the rationale behind the act.}

9f095c88-22cc-4641-8d6c-972a4c108e52.summary: Do reasons as explanations require conscious awareness?
9f095c88-22cc-4641-8d6c-972a4c108e52.content: {There is a plausible principle that explanations require the agent to be consciously aware of them. This principle together with actions done unconsciously entails that not all reasons for actions can serve as explanations.}, {A case where someone flinches instinctively at a loud noise does not involve a conscious reason that can explain their action.}

7c032255-6619-4d1b-8295-c02c9a00fbff.summary: Are emotional responses reasons in the same sense as rational deliberations?
7c032255-6619-4d1b-8295-c02c9a00fbff.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person cries at a sad movie. Intuitively, their tears are not explained by a rational choice but by an emotional response.}, {It is implausible that an emotional reaction, although a reason for tears, can fully explain or give a rationale behind choosing to cry.}

ca8a556a-4133-4425-b611-fdfcdbc6cf16.summary: Can reasons be purely normative without being explanatory?
ca8a556a-4133-4425-b611-fdfcdbc6cf16.content: {There is a plausible distinction between normative reasons, which suggest what ought to be done, and explanatory reasons, which provide understanding of an action taken.}, {Suppose a person says they ought to help others purely out of moral duty. Intuitively, this normative reason does not explain the causal mechanism of their action.}

4c753358-c1ea-434f-879e-fe0f917deb68.summary: Are all actions fully reducible to reasons with an explanatory role?
4c753358-c1ea-434f-879e-fe0f917deb68.content: {Consider a case in which someone acts spontaneously, such as singing in the shower without prior intent. Intuitively, this spontaneity lacks a linked understanding of the causal history.}, {It is implausible that every action, especially spontaneous ones, are reducible to reasons that serve as explanations.}

52e4bac4-f19a-4a68-9f14-facb6a0f8432.summary: Do explanations as reasons apply universally across cultures?
52e4bac4-f19a-4a68-9f14-facb6a0f8432.content: {Consider a scenario in which a cultural practice is performed, such as fasting during Ramadan. Intuitively, the reasons for these practices might differ and not serve as a universal explanatory framework when viewed externally.}, {It is implausible that reasons rooted in specific cultural contexts can always be universal explanations for actions across all cultures.}

59d561b6-f2a1-42ab-b2dc-8047afa20e52.summary: Can reason explanations account for all subjective experiences driving action?
59d561b6-f2a1-42ab-b2dc-8047afa20e52.content: {Suppose we have a case in which someone acts based on a fleeting feeling, such as a sudden urge to dance. Intuitively, these subjective experiences might not be fully captured by a reason that explains the action.}, {It is implausible that the subjective immediacy of an experience is always tied to a reason that clarifies the rationale behind such actions.}

6cccd14e-8c49-4aee-9eba-698eafaa8639.summary: Does every action have a clear rationale rooted in a reason?
6cccd14e-8c49-4aee-9eba-698eafaa8639.content: {A case where someone changes their mind last minute, like deciding on a whim to travel, challenges the notion that there is an always clear rationale or reason.}, {It is implausible that spontaneous choices are deeply understood through the lens of a rationale reason explanation.}

76285879-4317-4571-b24f-eb9a7bf80739.summary: Can values always determine reasons for action?
76285879-4317-4571-b24f-eb9a7bf80739.content: {Consider a scenario in which an agent holds personal values that are morally questionable, such as valuing discrimination. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that these values do not justify reasons that guide actions.}, {There is a plausible principle that only morally acceptable values should determine reasons for actions.}

d7460bb7-a4a0-4c90-8912-bdeb8c1b1d0f.summary: How do we handle conflicting values when determining reasons?
d7460bb7-a4a0-4c90-8912-bdeb8c1b1d0f.content: {Suppose we have a case where an agent holds two conflicting values equally, such as family loyalty and honesty. Intuitively, we either have to say that both values equally provide reasons or that neither provides a reason. If we say that both values provide reasons, then we face a contradiction in guidance. If we say neither provides a reason, then the concept of reasons loses its guiding role.}

4d99a4d9-59e9-42f3-ad64-d73d00da9497.summary: What about agents lacking ethical beliefs?
4d99a4d9-59e9-42f3-ad64-d73d00da9497.content: {A case in which an agent has no moral or ethical standards but acts consistently with self-interest poses a challenge to the idea that reasons must be linked to moral or ethical standards.}, {It is plausible that agents can have reasons for action that are not connected to ethical or moral standards if they consistently achieve self-interested goals.}

1ff3fef7-731e-40d0-840e-a29dba632c58.summary: Do all values lead to guidance for action?
1ff3fef7-731e-40d0-840e-a29dba632c58.content: {There are plausible situations where an agent values art for its own sake yet acknowledges it has no direct action-guiding implications.}, {It is implausible that all values inherently lead to reasons that guide actions.}

c73ac3c2-1782-4573-8fb6-d672d09d40be.summary: Can purely subjective values suffice for reasons?
c73ac3c2-1782-4573-8fb6-d672d09d40be.content: {Consider a scenario where an agent passionately values collecting bottle caps, but this has little to no intrinsic value to others. In such a scenario, intuitively, it seems that this subjective valuation might not offer a robust reason for action.}, {It is implausible that purely subjective or eccentric values can universally justify reasons for action.}

01ab3868-43d3-4ad9-a315-3192bbdafc5e.summary: What happens when different agents' values conflict?
01ab3868-43d3-4ad9-a315-3192bbdafc5e.content: {Suppose we have two agents with profoundly different value systems, such as one who values freedom above all and another who values security. Intuitively, we either have to say that both have equally valid reasons based on their values, or that neither has a true reason. If we say both have equally valid reasons, then real-world conflict resolution becomes impossible.}

485d48a9-386a-4d12-9f99-a868fd2cc569.summary: Are reasons always tied to what is considered important?
485d48a9-386a-4d12-9f99-a868fd2cc569.content: {A scenario in which an agent makes a decision based purely on whim rather than deliberating over what they consider important poses a challenge to the idea that reasons must reflect what is considered worthwhile.}, {It is plausible that reasons for action can arise from non-deliberative processes that do not necessarily reflect importance.}

b9b9e5be-38ed-4298-be81-a6d162bd46ae.summary: How does cultural relativism impact reasons as values?
b9b9e5be-38ed-4298-be81-a6d162bd46ae.content: {Consider a scenario where cultural values vary significantly, such as differing beliefs about the role of women in society. Intuitively, we might judge that cultural values should not always determine reasons for action due to ethical concerns.}, {A principle suggesting reasons are justified solely on local cultural values may conflict with universal ethical standards.}

6452206f-e97d-4025-8f93-73dd191da18e.summary: Are irrational values valid bases for reasons?
6452206f-e97d-4025-8f93-73dd191da18e.content: {A case in which an agent values an irrational belief, like thinking they must spin three times before making a decision, challenges the notion that values must provide a rational foundation for reasons for action.}, {It is implausible that irrational values can consistently provide valid reasons for guiding actions.}

732af2a5-4400-4f36-ba16-7c071d2b6373.summary: Do agents always act on reasons that align with values?
732af2a5-4400-4f36-ba16-7c071d2b6373.content: {Consider a scenario in which an agent values environmental conservation but routinely engages in activities that harm the environment. In such a scenario, intuitively, it seems that reasons guiding their actions may not align with their stated values.}, {There is a plausible principle that agents can have reasons for actions that deviate from their values due to external pressures or contrary desires.}

787df0f6-dde3-4b66-9964-7a06f5e08cd4.summary: Can reasons exist independently of an agent's goals?
787df0f6-dde3-4b66-9964-7a06f5e08cd4.content: {There is a plausible principle that reasons should apply universally, regardless of individual agent goals. This principle together with the view that reasons are linked to specific agent purposes suggests a conflict since goals vary widely between agents.}, {Consider a scenario where an agent has an immoral goal, like stealing for pleasure. Intuitively, there should not be a legitimate reason supporting immoral actions just because they align with an agent's goals.}

1fc41271-84ac-4845-88a8-7e36f031ed18.summary: Can reasons be objective if they are tied to subjective goals?
1fc41271-84ac-4845-88a8-7e36f031ed18.content: {A reason connected to the achievement of specific aims or objectives is contingent on subjective desires.}, {It is implausible that reasons, being contingent on subjective desires, maintain objective validity.}

1e90deb9-865c-48e4-9f4b-9a1e1bebb941.summary: Does every desired end justify the reasons supporting it?
1e90deb9-865c-48e4-9f4b-9a1e1bebb941.content: {A scenario where an agent desires the suffering of others for its own sake questions the legitimacy of reasons supporting this aim. Intuitively, such reasons should not be justified, pointing to a flaw in linking reasons strictly to desired end states.}

e859c908-a89a-4fbf-bdbe-f080a78deef5.summary: Is it possible for reasons to account for conflicting goals?
e859c908-a89a-4fbf-bdbe-f080a78deef5.content: {Suppose we have a case in which two agents have directly opposing goals, like wanting and not wanting a particular policy enforced. Intuitively, we either have to say that both have reasons supporting their goals or that neither does. If we say both have reasons, then reasons lose coherence; if we say neither does, the role of reasons in goal pursuit becomes void.}

1fb00d17-ce1a-4590-a8b8-8dd81acea79f.summary: Can teleological reasons explain actions with no apparent goal?
1fb00d17-ce1a-4590-a8b8-8dd81acea79f.content: {Consider a scenario where someone acts out of habit rather than for any explicit goal, such as tapping fingers while thinking. Intuitively, we would judge that articulating a reason for this behavior without a goal may be challenging.}

88e24327-0226-46a6-bb31-cc4a6814b85f.summary: Do teleological reasons fully capture acts of duty?
88e24327-0226-46a6-bb31-cc4a6814b85f.content: {A reason related to the achievement of specific aims or objectives seems insufficient in cases of duty, where actions are performed independently of personal goals.}, {There is a plausible principle that reasons should sometimes guide actions irrespective of goals, such as in the performance of duty. This principle together with the teleological view leads to a clash concerning duties that do not align with personal aims.}

40ad7dd1-a39d-42e1-93e1-9e1d6baf6765.summary: How do teleological reasons handle universal ethical principles?
40ad7dd1-a39d-42e1-93e1-9e1d6baf6765.content: {Ethical principles, like honesty or fairness, are generally treated as universal rather than goal-dependent.}, {A reason linked to the purposes or goals of an agent suggests such reasons are not universally applicable, creating tension with the ubiquity of ethical principles.}

4ac1466b-7a9f-45ce-98d8-5fc6c7cbf47f.summary: Can linking reasons to goals undermine autonomy?
4ac1466b-7a9f-45ce-98d8-5fc6c7cbf47f.content: {It is implausible that autonomy is upheld if reasons always reflect external goals.}, {Suppose an agent adopts goals imposed by others without deliberation. Intuitively, one might say the reasons in such cases do not genuinely express autonomy if they are simply goal-congruent.}

92d82465-43db-4617-98b9-26feaa397552.summary: Are reasons prescriptive if they are dependent on agent goals?
92d82465-43db-4617-98b9-26feaa397552.content: {A case in which an agent has a widely detrimental societal goal challenges the prescriptive nature of their reasons. Intuitively, such reasons would only ensure fulfillment for the individual without offering prescriptive force beyond the agent.}

75393afe-4388-4151-a9bd-577be3c9835a.summary: Can a reason exist without any connection to an agent's desires?
75393afe-4388-4151-a9bd-577be3c9835a.content: {There are reasons that apply to everyone regardless of their desires, such as moral obligations.}, {In a scenario where there is a universal moral law, an agent has a reason to act according to it even if they have no desire to follow it.}

2a93f3c7-9bd3-4c36-aa9a-6bdfa1d9ebe9.summary: Are there reasons that aren't derived from fulfilling preferences?
2a93f3c7-9bd3-4c36-aa9a-6bdfa1d9ebe9.content: {Occasionally, people feel compelled to act due to a sense of duty or obligation, independent of any personal preference.}, {Consider a person who helps others in need due to feeling compelled by moral obligation despite having no personal interest or desire to do so.}

d710d9f2-f2ea-4c87-b937-0427de093de9.summary: Could reasons exist that don't involve means-end reasoning?
d710d9f2-f2ea-4c87-b937-0427de093de9.content: {Some actions may be justified by abstract principles rather than a practical means-end analysis.}, {A case in which a person feels they have a reason to tell the truth simply because honesty is intrinsically valuable, regardless of any desire or outcome.}

fea91571-f492-490d-abfd-f1b2d8bb8d95.summary: Might reasons arise from social or cultural contexts rather than individual desires?
fea91571-f492-490d-abfd-f1b2d8bb8d95.content: {Cultural norms often provide reasons for conduct that are distinct from individual desires or preferences.}, {In a society that values hospitality, individuals might feel they have a reason to welcome strangers, regardless of their personal desires.}

b805218a-6fb8-4314-adba-c73a02661466.summary: Is a desire-based reason sufficient for all real-world decision-making?
b805218a-6fb8-4314-adba-c73a02661466.content: {Real-world decisions often involve conflicting reasons, some of which don't neatly align with individual desires.}, {When faced with a choice to report a wrongdoing, an employee may have reasons to do so tied to ethical considerations, regardless of personal desires.}

48d12665-b838-4f4a-90af-8fe0a19da2ca.summary: Can altruistic acts have reasons independent of self-interest?
48d12665-b838-4f4a-90af-8fe0a19da2ca.content: {Altruistic acts may be justifiable through reasons focused on others' well-being, not the agent's desires.}, {Someone donating anonymously to charity might have a reason grounded in the desire to help others, not in any benefit to themselves.}

7d828c15-ffdc-497c-b6bc-672f29befda7.summary: Is desire necessarily the foundation for all reasons agents deem worthwhile?
7d828c15-ffdc-497c-b6bc-672f29befda7.content: {There are reasons agents find worthwhile that might arise from principles or communal values rather than personal desires.}, {An agent might advocate for human rights internationally based on a reason tied to justice, regardless of personal desires.}

b25737bf-131d-4215-a7df-09d8a86c0b96.summary: Could a reason remain valid when an agent's preferences are uninformed or misguided?
b25737bf-131d-4215-a7df-09d8a86c0b96.content: {Preferences might be based on incomplete or false information, yet reasons still demand adherence regardless of those desires.}, {A scenario illustrates where someone refuses vaccination due to misguided fears, yet has medical reasons to do so despite their uninformed preference.}

282d741c-86f5-4938-a7da-6891603abc67.summary: Are all reasons reducible to an agent's motivational set?
282d741c-86f5-4938-a7da-6891603abc67.content: {Some philosophical theories suggest there exist reasons beyond an agent's subjective motivational framework.}, {An individual may acknowledge a reason to reduce ecological harm despite lacking any direct environmental concerns in their motivational set.}

c798ea65-1695-46c5-9977-37c618eb3d25.summary: Can a reason arise from an emotional response instead of a desire?
c798ea65-1695-46c5-9977-37c618eb3d25.content: {Emotional states can engender reasons for action independently of desires.}, {Experiencing empathy might provide a person with a reason to offer help, distinct from any prior desire.}

e4166786-7e54-4d4d-88c3-092ef3904466.summary: Is a reason necessarily derived from rational principles or duties?
e4166786-7e54-4d4d-88c3-092ef3904466.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person acts out of spontaneous kindness towards a stranger without adherence to any rational principles or duties. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the person's act still carries good reason.}, {There is a plausible principle that reasons for actions can emerge from emotions or instincts. This principle, together with the scenario of spontaneous kindness, entails that not all reasons are derived from rational principles or duties.}

3d93b9e4-2ce6-4fea-aae7-44402a9dc8e4.summary: Can a reason apply to all rational agents?
3d93b9e4-2ce6-4fea-aae7-44402a9dc8e4.content: {Consider a person who has a personal commitment to an artistic endeavor that requires them to devote substantial resources to their craft. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that their reason is not applicable to all rational agents.}, {It is plausible to think that reasons can be contingent upon individual circumstances and personal commitments, which cannot be universalized across all rational agents.}

04bd19e8-10fe-493e-9fcd-f4cc148e6a13.summary: Do reasons always align with moral laws or imperatives?
04bd19e8-10fe-493e-9fcd-f4cc148e6a13.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person lies to protect a friend from unjust harm. Intuitively, we either have to say that the person has a reason to protect their friend or that they do not. If we say they have a reason, then their reason does not align with the moral imperative against lying.}, {There is a plausible principle that personal loyalty can provide legitimate reasons even when they conflict with moral laws. This principle, together with the example of lying to protect a friend, entails that not all reasons align with moral laws or imperatives.}

53ed9fb1-dafe-41d9-bafb-92c8feefbe1f.content: {Consider a scenario in which a cultural tradition dictates a specific practice that has meaning and importance only within that particular community. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the reason for participating in this practice cannot be universalized to all communities or rational agents.}, {It is implausible that reasons grounded in cultural or traditional contexts can be made to apply to all rational agents universally, as such reasons are often deeply context-dependent.}

c3a4f7fc-90b0-446d-985f-b80df2e73a34.summary: Can duties generate reasons irrespective of personal values?
c3a4f7fc-90b0-446d-985f-b80df2e73a34.content: {Suppose a person believes they have a duty to care for a specific animal species; this duty generates reasons that are significant to them but may be irrelevant to others with different personal values.}, {It is plausible to think that duties derived from personal convictions can generate reasons that are not universally binding or significant to all rational agents.}

4f00489d-14b6-4102-b25f-08a6e84000a4.summary: Are reasons always relational properties only between an agent and an action?
4f00489d-14b6-4102-b25f-08a6e84000a4.content: {Consider a scenario in which an agent feels compelled to help someone without any specific action in mind. In such a scenario, intuitively we might judge that the agent has a reason to help, but not in relation to a specific action.}, {There is a plausible principle that reasons can exist independently of specific actions and instead prompt general inclinations towards certain kinds of action. This principle would suggest that not all reasons fit as relational properties strictly between an agent and an action.}

22757833-722a-4f35-92af-c3d8064c1794.summary: Can a reason exist without relating actions to appropriate ends?
22757833-722a-4f35-92af-c3d8064c1794.content: {Suppose we have a case where an agent has a strong belief that they should act kindly without any particular end goal. Intuitively, we might judge that the agent has a reason to act, even if there is no clearly defined appropriate end in mind.}, {It is plausible to assert that reasons can sometimes guide behavior even in the absence of specific appropriate ends to relate to actions.}

56857637-d3d9-4037-bd9b-6885ac086adf.summary: Is mediation between beliefs, desires, and actions necessary for a reason to exist?
56857637-d3d9-4037-bd9b-6885ac086adf.content: {Consider a case in which an agent acts purely out of instinct without any deliberate mediation between beliefs, desires, and actions. Intuitively, one might consider this action to be reason-driven, even without conscious mediation.}, {It is not implausible to suggest that reasons might operate at an instinctive level, bypassing any mediation between beliefs and desires.}

bb293b6e-058b-471d-9ceb-1ed6d19905ec.summary: Can reasons be independent of an agent's capacity and still be valid?
bb293b6e-058b-471d-9ceb-1ed6d19905ec.content: {Imagine a situation where an individual is cognitively impaired, unable to effectively relate actions to ends, yet we still view their instinctual protective actions towards their family as reason-driven. Intuitively, this suggests that the capacity to relate action to ends might not be essential for having a reason.}, {There is a plausible principle that acknowledges reasons can exist irrespective of compromised cognitive capacities that hinder the relational aspect.}

dab1f4d8-d5ec-4c22-96d0-37783ede6789.summary: Do reasons necessarily mediate between only beliefs, desires, and actions, or can they include emotions?
dab1f4d8-d5ec-4c22-96d0-37783ede6789.content: {Consider an instance where an agent feels profound fear, prompting immediate escape actions. Intuitively, this supports the idea that emotions, beyond beliefs and desires, can shape actions and constitute reasons.}, {It is plausible to extend reasons to encompass mediating roles between emotions and actions as well as beliefs and desires.}

16f94c59-ebaf-4ff4-9fed-c9b85ac24107.summary: Can a reason be present without resulting in or relating to an action at all?
16f94c59-ebaf-4ff4-9fed-c9b85ac24107.content: {There is a plausible principle that having a reason does not necessarily require it to relate to a specific action, but can reside in the reflection or deliberation itself.}, {Consider an individual reflecting deeply on a moral dilemma but unable or unwilling to act on it, intuitively suggesting the presence of a reason in the thoughtful process rather than in action.}

4bb17c31-f977-4688-bfd8-99613091a6b9.summary: Do reasons always need to result in clear ends, or can they guide ongoing processes without specific endpoints?
4bb17c31-f977-4688-bfd8-99613091a6b9.content: {Imagine an artist who is driven by a reason to keep creating art for personal satisfaction rather than achieving a specific recognized end. Intuitively, this suggests that a reason might guide a continuous process without a clear end.}, {It is plausible that reasons might exist not as relational properties to particular ends, but rather as ongoing motivations for a sustained process.}

a94815cd-7aa9-491a-ada3-44a800777796.summary: Is the relational property of reasons definitive if an agent's action is due to compulsion or coercion?
a94815cd-7aa9-491a-ada3-44a800777796.content: {Consider a scenario where an agent performs an action under duress or compulsion without endorsing the action as their own. We might judge that such actions are not guided by the agent's reasons, casting doubt on the obligatory nature of the relational property in such cases.}, {There is a plausible principle suggesting that actions under compulsion may appear as reasons-driven even if they lack genuine relational properties between agent and action.}

0859ee96-f252-44eb-8dcb-295bf88b0c1e.summary: Do reasons require explicit logical mediation between beliefs, desires, and actions, or can they be implicit?
0859ee96-f252-44eb-8dcb-295bf88b0c1e.content: {Suppose we have a case where an agent acts based on unexamined social norms that inform their behavior implicitly rather than through explicit mediation. We might judge this as reason-driven behavior without clear logical mediation.}, {It is plausible to assert that reasons might operate implicitly, informing actions through social and cultural frameworks rather than through direct mediation of beliefs and desires.}

16496400-b290-4f78-b17d-fb3d92afd5eb.summary: Can reasons exist outside the spectrum of an agent's conscious reflections?
16496400-b290-4f78-b17d-fb3d92afd5eb.content: {Consider a case where an agent acts spontaneously without conscious reflection, yet we still ascribe a reason for their action based on subconscious values or instincts. This suggests that reasons could exist outside explicit conscious reflection.}, {It is plausible that reasons might reside in subconscious drives and instincts, rather than requiring the agent's conscious capacity to relate to actions and ends.}

7401dd9c-c4bf-4dfd-8862-b259250d3a5d.summary: Can reasons exist independently of an agent's deliberation?
7401dd9c-c4bf-4dfd-8862-b259250d3a5d.content: {There is a plausible principle that reasons can exist independently of an individual's deliberation. This principle together with the view suggests that reasons must precede and be independent from personal reflection, which contradicts the idea that reasons are constructed.}, {Consider a scenario in which someone has a reason to avoid touching a hot stove because it will cause pain. In such a scenario, intuitively we would judge that the reason exists whether or not the person engages in practical deliberation.}

aefb2fa6-825f-4d2b-8ead-5088a3a65450.summary: Are there universally valid reasons that are not constructed by individuals?
aefb2fa6-825f-4d2b-8ead-5088a3a65450.content: {It is implausible that moral reasons, which are often considered universally valid, are constructed by individuals since their validity seems to depend on objective standards.}, {A case in which a person believes lying is wrong and reflects on the implications does not change the universal moral reason against lying, which appears not to be constructed through personal reflection.}

c405e699-977f-4e18-b0b0-0844cde3f7c0.summary: Can people hold irrational beliefs despite reflective endorsement?
c405e699-977f-4e18-b0b0-0844cde3f7c0.content: {Suppose we have a case in which a person reflectively endorses a belief in a known falsehood due to emotional biases. Intuitively, we either have to say that their reason is rational due to their endorsement or irrational due to the falsehood. If we say it is rational, then reasons become too easily manipulated by non-rational influences. If we say it is irrational, then reasons are not entirely a construction of rational reflection.}

541fa5f9-fc4d-41e4-af1e-7b3927111d3e.summary: Is it possible for two people to construct conflicting reasons?
541fa5f9-fc4d-41e4-af1e-7b3927111d3e.content: {Consider a scenario in which two people deliberate and reach opposed yet sincere conclusions about what they have reason to do. Intuitively we would judge that both have valid reasons if reasons are constructed individually, but this leads to the issue of contradictory reasons having equal validity.}

3fca5002-7ccd-4526-ad59-5d897abe0971.summary: Do reasons lose normative force if solely constructed by the agent?
3fca5002-7ccd-4526-ad59-5d897abe0971.content: {There is a plausible principle that normative force comes from reasons being beyond personal creation, binding individuals regardless of personal desires or inclinations. This principle together with the idea that reasons are constructed exclusively by agents suggests that they might lose their normative force.}

0bea2f9e-ae28-4016-9741-54440d4d9aa6.summary: Can reasons exist independently of emotional responses?
0bea2f9e-ae28-4016-9741-54440d4d9aa6.content: {Consider a scenario in which a person makes a moral decision based purely on logical deliberation without any emotional response. Intuitively, we would judge that this person still has a reason for their decision.}, {There is a plausible principle that reasons can be based on rational deliberation alone, without the necessity of emotional responses. This principle together with the above scenario entails that reasons can exist independently of emotional responses.}

1edde2ba-0e6a-4880-bf6e-abe973e29fe4.summary: Are affective states always necessary for reasoning?
1edde2ba-0e6a-4880-bf6e-abe973e29fe4.content: {Suppose we have a case in which an individual acts based on a principle of justice, yet this individual experiences no affective states while deciding or acting. Intuitively, we would say this individual still has a reason for their action.}, {It is implausible that an individual must necessarily experience affective states to possess valid reasons for their actions.}

dac4d6ae-4caa-4aed-b7e8-00f82160ce87.summary: Is motivational influence a necessary component of all reasons?
dac4d6ae-4caa-4aed-b7e8-00f82160ce87.content: {Consider a scenario in which an individual believes they ought to donate to charity, but they do not feel motivated to do so. Intuitively, we still say they have a reason to donate based on their belief.}, {There is a plausible principle that a reason can be valid even in the absence of motivational influence. This principle together with the above scenario entails that motivational influence is not necessary for something to be considered a reason.}

c2cc35b6-9224-4539-b7d3-1d6bf3fcf9dd.content: {Consider a scenario where a scientist carefully analyzes data and concludes she should publish her findings. This decision is based on cognitive evaluation rather than emotional response, yet it seems she has a compelling reason to publish.}, {It is implausible that emotional responses are required for cognitive evaluations or decisions to be considered reasons.}

f92790ce-5573-4baf-819a-ee4afd149da2.summary: Do emotional responses always align with good reasons?
f92790ce-5573-4baf-819a-ee4afd149da2.content: {There is a plausible principle that sometimes emotional responses misguide us rather than provide valid reasons, evident in cases of irrational fears or biases.}, {Suppose we have a case where someone avoids speaking in public due to anxiety, even though rational deliberation would suggest there are no negative outcomes. Intuitively, we would say that the anxiety is not a good reason to avoid speaking.}

7587e22e-1ed8-4bd3-9ba2-5ee2554a68f4.summary: Can reasons prescriptively guide actions without emotions?
7587e22e-1ed8-4bd3-9ba2-5ee2554a68f4.content: {Suppose we have a case where an individual formally recognizes they should exercise more for health reasons, but they lack any emotional inclination to do so. Intuitively, this recognition still functions as a prescriptive reason to exercise more.}, {It is implausible that emotions are required for reasons to serve a prescriptive function in guiding actions.}
